text: So I would comment on that. I agree. I think that right now what we're working on is really just transitioning into dealing with what's right in front of us.  I was alarmed by what it showed in terms of the COVID slide, but I think more alarming is when you look at those same slide decks, you'll see the summer slide that occurs for students annually. And it's most impactful with students who are underprivileged. So one of the things we've been talking about at the cabinet level,  and we're starting to gather some of our own data around is studying our own summer slide and the annual impact that it has on student learning. There's a lot of mythology about whether or not underprivileged students can learn at the same rate as their peers. The absolute fact is that they can. There's also a lot of mythology around whether or not  the kind of instructional practices that we use for all children are as impactful with underprivileged students. And the truth is that they are. And looking at our data from a national level, you would see that during the course of a school year, all students make the same kind of progress. And in some years, in fact,  the quote unquote underprivileged students exceed their more wealthy peers in terms of progress. Our teachers are highly effective. They get great results with their students. And every summer, because some students have more access to continuous cultivation throughout the summer that other students do not, there's the summer slide. And so,  the students who have opportunities during the summer to enrich and extend their learning, come back to school with actual growth that occurs during that summer period, which continues to put them ahead of their marginalized peers. So there's one of the things that I would consider structuring into another retreat with the board at some point,  would be to start off by reading a section from Malcolm Gladwell's book that's called Outliers where he lays out in stark detail the impact of the summer slide and the very promising detail that if we take measures to eliminate an extended summer break by spreading the school year evenly over  of what we currently use as this agrarian calendar, but instead move to where we spread the school year evenly over the 365 day year, you can virtually eliminate that slide. It will level the playing field for students and provide multiple opportunities throughout the year for students to catch up on their learning if they need to.  and also for teachers to engage in voluntary professional development to deal with the needs of students right in front of them during that time. I'm putting the cart a little bit before the horse by talking about this because it's really something that we're currently just studying. Last week, I had a meeting with Debbie, Chris Gilman, Mark Leach, and also Sarah Duesenberry and Christine Diggs  because what I want to do is to look at our own data for Albemarle County schools and replicate the tables that are in Malcolm Gladwell's book so that we can show people that we in fact have the same kind of summer slide that other places experience. And I think we did land on some data that we could use with map testing in elementary school because that's given  in the fall and the spring. You need to have something that you can look at fall, spring, fall again so that you can see what the impact of the summer slide is. Because I know lots of times people have an understanding of something at the national level and even the state level, but they need to see it for themselves locally so that they understand we have some of the same issues that you have in other places. So Kate, I'm really glad you brought that up.  We've also done a little bit of preliminary research with the Education Advisory Board to get insights around how other high-performing school systems around the country implement extended learning time. And what I would want to avoid is a conversation of just something called a year-round calendar. There's certain branding that goes with that that can infuriate people. However, I think that  Talking about an adjusted calendar that extends over the course of a 365 day year is more of a recovery calendar. And I think that we would want to have that in as a tool in our tool belt, moving forward as a school system, so that there's that option for families, at least in each feeder pattern, to have an extended, what I would call a recovery calendar, because it's a fact.  Katrina was not just screaming in the wind. It is an absolute fact that our kindergarten students, first grade students, there are finite skills that they only really have so much time to learn and build so that they become competent readers later that without addressing  and accelerating and catching them up, they're going to be behind where they should be. And I do think that having a recovery calendar in place for four or maybe five years minimum after this will be a necessity. And then it's a question of once people experience a calendar that stretches through the whole year, I think in most places and what we've seen in the research is they don't want to go back.  So I just thought I'd put that on the table as a more of a futuristic topic of discussion. I'm certainly interested in hearing the board kick it around. Matt, I was talking with DJ this morning about that exact issue.
